3245.text:

3258.text:

3293.text:
"He first laughed at my words, and then frowned

3299.text:

3304.text:
"'Doctor, finding my brother in this difficulty

3311.text:
aid should be invited. Your reputation is

to make, you are probably mindful of your

"'Monsieur,' said I, 'in my profession, the

had heard and seen.

as I resumed my seat, I found both the brothers

I could understand some few syllables that

her lips. She asked me where she was, and

fast, and could not live another day. Until

cases to which I had been summoned, and the

all the circumstances. I knew what Court influence

were, and I expected that the matter would

3614.text:
my own mind. I had kept the matter a profound

3621.text:

3656.text:
*****

3662.text:

3670.text:

but not marked for long life. She was in great

3683.text:

3689.text:
elder brother, with the initial letter embroidered

"My memory is still accurate, but I cannot

3706.text:
that I am watched more closely than I was,

3720.text:
husband's share in it, and my being resorted

3733.text:

3738.text:
the suffering many.

3742.text:

3748.text:
her nothing but that there was such a sister;

to come to me, relying on my confidence, had

3759.text:
and place of abode. Whereas, to this wretched

from me, with a warning, yesterday. I must

3789.text:

3795.text:
in dread of him, and in dread of her husband

3801.text:
was a child, a pretty boy from two to three

3806.text:

3813.text:

3819.text:
a presentiment that if no other innocent atonement

3826.text:
of him. What I have left to call my own—it

3833.text:
will make it the first charge of his life

of his dead mother, on this injured family,

3844.text:
"She kissed the boy, and said, caressing him,

3852.text:
be faithful, little Charles?' The child answered

3859.text:
she took him in her arms, and went away caressing

3865.text:
"As she had mentioned her husband's name in

3871.text:
of it to my letter. I sealed my letter, and,

3876.text:
it myself that day.

3882.text:
nine o'clock, a man in a black dress rang

3888.text:
followed my servant, Ernest Defarge, a youth,

3895.text:
where I sat with my wife—O my wife, beloved

3902.text:
saw the man, who was supposed to be at the

3907.text:
"An urgent case in the Rue St. Honore, he

3913.text:

3924.text:
and my arms were pinioned. The two brothers

me with a single gesture. The Marquis took

3936.text:
showed it me, burnt it in the light of a lantern

3941.text:
with his foot. Not a word was spoken. I was

3949.text:
"If it had pleased _God_ to put it in the

3955.text:
these frightful years, to grant me any tidings

3961.text:
know by a word whether alive or dead—I might

3968.text:
them. But, now I believe that the mark of

3975.text:
have no part in His mercies. And them and

3985.text:

3996.text:
agony, denounce to the times when all these

to Heaven and to earth."

4027.text:
there was not a head in the nation but must

4064.text:
day, against such denunciation.

good physician of the Republic would deserve

4163.text:
doomed to die, fell under the sentence, as
if she had been mortally stricken. But, she

4169.text:
uttered no sound; and so strong was the voice
within her, representing that it was she of

4176.text:
all the world who must uphold him in his misery

4183.text:
her, even from that shock.

4189.text:
demonstration out of doors, the Tribunal adjourned.

4195.text:
emptying itself by many passages had not ceased,

4202.text:
her husband, with nothing in her face but
love and consolation.

4207.text:
"If I might touch him! If I might embrace

4214.text:
so much compassion for us!"
There was but a gaoler left, along with two

4221.text:
of the four men who had taken him last night,

4228.text:
to the show in the streets. Barsad proposed

4234.text:
is but a moment." It was silently acquiesced

4240.text:
the hall to a raised place, where he, by leaning

4246.text:
"Farewell, dear darling of my soul. My parting
blessing on my love. We shall meet again,

4254.text:
where the weary are at rest!"

4259.text:
her to his bosom.
"I can bear it, dear Charles. I am supported

4265.text:
from above: don't suffer for me. A parting

4270.text:

4278.text:
"My husband. No! A moment!" He was tearing

4288.text:
long. I feel that this will break my heart

4293.text:
can, and when I leave her, God will raise

4301.text:

4306.text:

4313.text:

4319.text:
now what you underwent when you suspected

4324.text:

4331.text:
you with all our hearts, and all our love

4338.text:

4344.text:

4349.text:
"All things have worked together as they have
fallen out. It was the always-vain endeavour

4355.text:

4362.text:

4376.text:
and stood looking after him with her hands

4382.text:
and with a radiant look upon her face, in

4394.text:

4408.text:

4414.text:

4424.text:

4430.text:
their old friend got into it, and he took

4436.text:

4441.text:
to picture to himself on which of the rough

4452.text:

her to consciousness, while she only faints."

4482.text:
papa! O, look at her, dear Carton! Can you,

4488.text:
her so?"

4492.text:
cheek against his face. He put her gently

4539.text:

are they not?"

4548.text:
from me. I had the strongest assurances that

4561.text:

together, "such great things as this. But

4606.text:

4628.text:

nine, shall I hear what you have done, either

4649.text:

"If any one of these men, or all of these

4666.text:

4684.text:

4735.text:
decided where to go. "At Tellson's banking-house
at nine," he said, with a musing face. "Shall

4742.text:
I do well, in the mean time, to show myself?

know there is such a man as I here; it is

4754.text:
preparation. But care, care, care! Let me

4760.text:

4766.text:
the already darkening street, and traced the
thought in his mind to its possible consequences.

people should know there is such a man as

Antoine.

the city well, to find his house without asking

4809.text:
sound asleep after dinner. For the first time

the brandy slowly down on Mr. Lorry's hearth

a mirror, and slightly altered the disordered

and his wild hair. This done, he went on direct

5482.text:

Chapter XIII. Fifty-two
In the black prison of the Conciergerie, the

6017.text:
doomed of the day awaited their fate. They
were in number as the weeks of the year. Fifty-two

6023.text:
were to roll that afternoon on the life-tide
of the city to the boundless everlasting sea.

6030.text:
Before their cells were quit of them, new
occupants were appointed; before their blood

6035.text:
ran into the blood spilled yesterday, the
blood that was to mingle with theirs to-morrow

6040.text:
was already set apart.
Two score and twelve were told off. From the

6046.text:
farmer-general of seventy, whose riches could
not buy his life, to the seamstress of twenty,

6053.text:
whose poverty and obscurity could not save
her. Physical diseases, engendered in the

6059.text:
vices and neglects of men, will seize on victims
of all degrees; and the frightful moral disorder,

6066.text:
born of unspeakable suffering, intolerable
oppression, and heartless indifference, smote

6073.text:
equally without distinction.
Charles Darnay, alone in a cell, had sustained

6081.text:
himself with no flattering delusion since
he came to it from the Tribunal. In every

6086.text:
line of the narrative he had heard, he had
heard his condemnation. He had fully comprehended

6093.text:
that no personal influence could possibly
save him, that he was virtually sentenced

6099.text:
by the millions, and that units could avail
him nothing.

6103.text:
Nevertheless, it was not easy, with the face
of his beloved wife fresh before him, to compose

6109.text:
his mind to what it must bear. His hold on
life was strong, and it was very, very hard,

6116.text:
to loosen; by gradual efforts and degrees

6123.text:
there; and when he brought his strength to
bear on that hand and it yielded, this was

6129.text:
closed again. There was a hurry, too, in all
his thoughts, a turbulent and heated working

6136.text:
of his heart, that contended against resignation.
If, for a moment, he did feel resigned, then

6143.text:
his wife and child who had to live after him,
seemed to protest and to make it a selfish

6149.text:
thing.
But, all this was at first. Before long, the

6154.text:
consideration that there was no disgrace in
the fate he must meet, and that numbers went

6159.text:
the same road wrongfully, and trod it firmly
every day, sprang up to stimulate him. Next

6167.text:
followed the thought that much of the future
peace of mind enjoyable by the dear ones,

6173.text:
depended on his quiet fortitude. So, by degrees
he calmed into the better state, when he could

6181.text:
raise his thoughts much higher, and draw comfort
down.

6187.text:
Before it had set in dark on the night of
his condemnation, he had travelled thus far

6192.text:

the means of writing, and a light, he sat

6199.text:

6205.text:

that he had known nothing of her father's

6210.text:
imprisonment, until he had heard of it from
herself, and that he had been as ignorant

6215.text:
as she of his father's and uncle's responsibility
for that misery, until the paper had been

6221.text:
read. He had already explained to her that

6226.text:
had relinquished, was the one condition—fully
intelligible now—that her father had attached

6233.text:

6238.text:

6244.text:

6249.text:
the moment, or for good), by the story of
the Tower, on that old Sunday under the dear

6255.text:
old plane-tree in the garden. If he had preserved
any definite remembrance of it, there could

6261.text:
be no doubt that he had supposed it destroyed
with the Bastille, when he had found no mention

6267.text:
of it among the relics of prisoners which
the populace had discovered there, and which

6272.text:
had been described to all the world. He besought
her—though he added that he knew it was

6277.text:

him through every tender means she could think

6284.text:

for which he could justly reproach himself,

6289.text:
but had uniformly forgotten himself for their

6296.text:

6302.text:
to their dear child, he adjured her, as they

6312.text:

6318.text:
confided his wife and child to his care. And

6324.text:

6331.text:
he might be tending.

6343.text:

6350.text:
that he never once thought of him.

6355.text:

6361.text:

6367.text:

6373.text:

6379.text:
again, and she told him it was all a dream,

6386.text:

6391.text:

6397.text:

6403.text:

6409.text:

6416.text:

a new action began in his waking thoughts,

6422.text:
which was very difficult to master.

6427.text:
to terminate his life. How high it was from
the ground, how many steps it had, where he

6433.text:
would be stood, how he would be touched, whether
the touching hands would be dyed red, which

6439.text:

be the first, or might be the last: these

6444.text:

by his will, obtruded themselves over and

6451.text:
over again, countless times. Neither were

6458.text:
of no fear. Rather, they originated in a strange
besetting desire to know what to do when the

6465.text:

8048.text:
Three, in a low voice. "We really have not
heads enough; it would be a pity, I think."

8055.text:
"He was signalling with her when I saw her,"
argued Madame Defarge; "I cannot speak of

8062.text:
one without the other; and I must not be silent,
and trust the case wholly to him, this little

8068.text:
citizen here. For, I am not a bad witness."
The Vengeance and Jacques Three vied with

8074.text:
each other in their fervent protestations
that she was the most admirable and marvellous

8080.text:
of witnesses. The little citizen, not to be
outdone, declared her to be a celestial witness.

8087.text:
"He must take his chance," said Madame Defarge.
"No, I cannot spare him! You are engaged at

8094.text:
three o'clock; you are going to see the batch
of to-day executed.—You?"

8100.text:
The question was addressed to the wood-sawyer,
who hurriedly replied in the affirmative:

8105.text:
seizing the occasion to add that he was the
most ardent of Republicans, and that he would

8110.text:
be in effect the most desolate of Republicans,
if anything prevented him from enjoying the

8116.text:
pleasure of smoking his afternoon pipe in
the contemplation of the droll national barber.

8124.text:
He was so very demonstrative herein, that
he might have been suspected (perhaps was,

8129.text:
by the dark eyes that looked contemptuously
at him out of Madame Defarge's head) of having

8135.text:
his small individual fears for his own personal
safety, every hour in the day.

8143.text:
"I," said madame, "am equally engaged at the
same place. After it is over—say at eight

8150.text:
to-night—come you to me, in Saint Antoine,
and we will give information against these

8156.text:
people at my Section."
The wood-sawyer said he would be proud and

8161.text:
flattered to attend the citizeness. The citizeness
looking at him, he became embarrassed, evaded

8167.text:
her glance as a small dog would have done,
retreated among his wood, and hid his confusion

8174.text:
over the handle of his saw.
Madame Defarge beckoned the Juryman and The

8180.text:
Vengeance a little nearer to the door, and
there expounded her further views to them

8186.text:
thus:
"She will now be at home, awaiting the moment

8191.text:
of his death. She will be mourning and grieving.
She will be in a state of mind to impeach

8197.text:
the justice of the Republic. She will be full
of sympathy with its enemies. I will go to

8202.text:
her."
"What an admirable woman; what an adorable

8207.text:
woman!" exclaimed Jacques Three, rapturously.
"Ah, my cherished!" cried The Vengeance; and

8214.text:
embraced her.
"Take you my knitting," said Madame Defarge,

8219.text:
placing it in her lieutenant's hands, "and
have it ready for me in my usual seat. Keep

8224.text:
me my usual chair. Go you there, straight,
for there will probably be a greater concourse

8230.text:
than usual, to-day."
"I willingly obey the orders of my Chief,"

8234.text:
said The Vengeance with alacrity, and kissing
her cheek. "You will not be late?"

8240.text:
"I shall be there before the commencement."
"And before the tumbrils arrive. Be sure you

8246.text:
are there, my soul," said The Vengeance, calling
after her, for she had already turned into

8251.text:
the street, "before the tumbrils arrive!"
Madame Defarge slightly waved her hand, to

8259.text:
imply that she heard, and might be relied
upon to arrive in good time, and so went through

8264.text:
the mud, and round the corner of the prison
wall. The Vengeance and the Juryman, looking

8270.text:
after her as she walked away, were highly
appreciative of her fine figure, and her superb

8276.text:
moral endowments.
There were many women at that time, upon whom

8281.text:
the time laid a dreadfully disfiguring hand;
but, there was not one among them more to

8288.text:
be dreaded than this ruthless woman, now taking
her way along the streets. Of a strong and

8294.text:
fearless character, of shrewd sense and readiness,
of great determination, of that kind of beauty

8302.text:
which not only seems to impart to its possessor
firmness and animosity, but to strike into

8308.text:
others an instinctive recognition of those
qualities; the troubled time would have heaved

8314.text:
her up, under any circumstances. But, imbued
from her childhood with a brooding sense of

8321.text:
wrong, and an inveterate hatred of a class,
opportunity had developed her into a tigress.

8329.text:
She was absolutely without pity. If she had
ever had the virtue in her, it had quite gone

8335.text:
out of her.
It was nothing to her, that an innocent man

8339.text:
was to die for the sins of his forefathers;
she saw, not him, but them. It was nothing

8346.text:
to her, that his wife was to be made a widow
and his daughter an orphan; that was insufficient

8352.text:
punishment, because they were her natural
enemies and her prey, and as such had no right

8359.text:
to live. To appeal to her, was made hopeless
by her having no sense of pity, even for herself.

8366.text:
If she had been laid low in the streets, in
any of the many encounters in which she had

8372.text:
been engaged, she would not have pitied herself;
nor, if she had been ordered to the axe to-morrow,

8378.text:
would she have gone to it with any softer
feeling than a fierce desire to change places

8383.text:
with the man who sent her there.
Such a heart Madame Defarge carried under

8389.text:
her rough robe. Carelessly worn, it was a
becoming robe enough, in a certain weird way,

8396.text:
and her dark hair looked rich under her coarse
red cap. Lying hidden in her bosom, was a

8402.text:
loaded pistol. Lying hidden at her waist,
was a sharpened dagger. Thus accoutred, and

8409.text:
walking with the confident tread of such a
character, and with the supple freedom of

8414.text:
a woman who had habitually walked in her girlhood,
bare-foot and bare-legged, on the brown sea-sand,

8421.text:
Madame Defarge took her way along the streets.
Now, when the journey of the travelling coach,

8428.text:
at that very moment waiting for the completion
of its load, had been planned out last night,

8433.text:
the difficulty of taking Miss Pross in it
had much engaged Mr. Lorry's attention. It

8439.text:
was not merely desirable to avoid overloading
the coach, but it was of the highest importance

8446.text:
that the time occupied in examining it and
its passengers, should be reduced to the utmost;

8452.text:
since their escape might depend on the saving
of only a few seconds here and there. Finally,

8459.text:
he had proposed, after anxious consideration,
that Miss Pross and Jerry, who were at liberty

8465.text:
to leave the city, should leave it at three
o'clock in the lightest-wheeled conveyance

8470.text:
known to that period. Unencumbered with luggage,
they would soon overtake the coach, and, passing

8477.text:
it and preceding it on the road, would order
its horses in advance, and greatly facilitate

8483.text:
its progress during the precious hours of
the night, when delay was the most to be dreaded.

8490.text:
Seeing in this arrangement the hope of rendering
real service in that pressing emergency, Miss

8497.text:
Pross hailed it with joy. She and Jerry had
beheld the coach start, had known who it was

8503.text:
that Solomon brought, had passed some ten
minutes in tortures of suspense, and were

8508.text:
now concluding their arrangements to follow
the coach, even as Madame Defarge, taking

8514.text:
her way through the streets, now drew nearer
and nearer to the else-deserted lodging in

8520.text:
which they held their consultation.
"Now what do you think, Mr. Cruncher," said

8526.text:
Miss Pross, whose agitation was so great that
she could hardly speak, or stand, or move,

8532.text:
or live: "what do you think of our not starting
from this courtyard? Another carriage having

8537.text:
already gone from here to-day, it might awaken
suspicion."

8540.text:
"My opinion, miss," returned Mr. Cruncher,
"is as you're right. Likewise wot I'll stand

8547.text:
by you, right or wrong."
"I am so distracted with fear and hope for

8553.text:
our precious creatures," said Miss Pross,
wildly crying, "that I am incapable of forming

8559.text:
any plan. Are _you_ capable of forming any
plan, my dear good Mr. Cruncher?"

8565.text:
"Respectin' a future spear o' life, miss,"
returned Mr. Cruncher, "I hope so. Respectin'

8573.text:
any present use o' this here blessed old head
o' mine, I think not. Would you do me the

8579.text:
favour, miss, to take notice o' two promises
and wows wot it is my wishes fur to record

8585.text:
in this here crisis?"
"Oh, for gracious sake!" cried Miss Pross,

8591.text:
still wildly crying, "record them at once,
and get them out of the way, like an excellent

8597.text:
man."
"First," said Mr. Cruncher, who was all in

8601.text:
a tremble, and who spoke with an ashy and
solemn visage, "them poor things well out

8607.text:
o' this, never no more will I do it, never
no more!"

8611.text:
"I am quite sure, Mr. Cruncher," returned
Miss Pross, "that you never will do it again,

8617.text:
whatever it is, and I beg you not to think
it necessary to mention more particularly

8622.text:
what it is."
"No, miss," returned Jerry, "it shall not

8626.text:
be named to you. Second: them poor things
well out o' this, and never no more will I

8632.text:
interfere with Mrs. Cruncher's flopping, never
no more!"

8636.text:
"Whatever housekeeping arrangement that may
be," said Miss Pross, striving to dry her

8641.text:
eyes and compose herself, "I have no doubt
it is best that Mrs. Cruncher should have

8647.text:
it entirely under her own superintendence.—O
my poor darlings!"

8652.text:
"I go so far as to say, miss, moreover," proceeded
Mr. Cruncher, with a most alarming tendency

8661.text:
to hold forth as from a pulpit—"and let
my words be took down and took to Mrs. Cruncher

8668.text:
through yourself—that wot my opinions respectin'
flopping has undergone a change, and that

8674.text:
wot I only hope with all my heart as Mrs.
Cruncher may be a flopping at the present

8678.text:
time."
"There, there, there! I hope she is, my dear

8683.text:
man," cried the distracted Miss Pross, "and
I hope she finds it answering her expectations."

8689.text:
"Forbid it," proceeded Mr. Cruncher, with
additional solemnity, additional slowness,

8696.text:
and additional tendency to hold forth and
hold out, "as anything wot I have ever said

8702.text:
or done should be wisited on my earnest wishes
for them poor creeturs now! Forbid it as we

8709.text:
shouldn't all flop (if it was anyways conwenient)
to get 'em out o' this here dismal risk! Forbid

8716.text:
it, miss! Wot I say, for-_bid_ it!" This was
Mr. Cruncher's conclusion after a protracted

8724.text:
but vain endeavour to find a better one.
And still Madame Defarge, pursuing her way

8731.text:
along the streets, came nearer and nearer.
"If we ever get back to our native land,"

8738.text:
said Miss Pross, "you may rely upon my telling
Mrs. Cruncher as much as I may be able to

8744.text:
remember and understand of what you have so
impressively said; and at all events you may

8749.text:
be sure that I shall bear witness to your
being thoroughly in earnest at this dreadful

8755.text:
time. Now, pray let us think! My esteemed
Mr. Cruncher, let us think!"

8761.text:
Still, Madame Defarge, pursuing her way along
the streets, came nearer and nearer.

8769.text:
"If you were to go before," said Miss Pross,
"and stop the vehicle and horses from coming

8775.text:
here, and were to wait somewhere for me; wouldn't
that be best?"

8780.text:
Mr. Cruncher thought it might be best.
"Where could you wait for me?" asked Miss

8785.text:
Pross.
Mr. Cruncher was so bewildered that he could

8788.text:
think of no locality but Temple Bar. Alas!
Temple Bar was hundreds of miles away, and

8795.text:
Madame Defarge was drawing very near indeed.
"By the cathedral door," said Miss Pross.

8803.text:
"Would it be much out of the way, to take
me in, near the great cathedral door between

8808.text:
the two towers?"
"No, miss," answered Mr. Cruncher.

8812.text:
"Then, like the best of men," said Miss Pross,
"go to the posting-house straight, and make

8818.text:
that change."
"I am doubtful," said Mr. Cruncher, hesitating

8823.text:
and shaking his head, "about leaving of you,
you see. We don't know what may happen."

8829.text:
"Heaven knows we don't," returned Miss Pross,
"but have no fear for me. Take me in at the

8835.text:
cathedral, at Three o'Clock, or as near it
as you can, and I am sure it will be better

8840.text:
than our going from here. I feel certain of
it. There! Bless you, Mr. Cruncher! Think-not

8846.text:
of me, but of the lives that may depend on
both of us!"

8851.text:
This exordium, and Miss Pross's two hands
in quite agonised entreaty clasping his, decided

8858.text:
Mr. Cruncher. With an encouraging nod or two,
he immediately went out to alter the arrangements,

8865.text:
and left her by herself to follow as she had
proposed.

8869.text:
The having originated a precaution which was
already in course of execution, was a great

8875.text:
relief to Miss Pross. The necessity of composing
her appearance so that it should attract no

8881.text:
special notice in the streets, was another
relief. She looked at her watch, and it was

8886.text:
twenty minutes past two. She had no time to
lose, but must get ready at once.

8893.text:
Afraid, in her extreme perturbation, of the
loneliness of the deserted rooms, and of half-imagined

8900.text:
faces peeping from behind every open door
in them, Miss Pross got a basin of cold water

8906.text:
and began laving her eyes, which were swollen
and red. Haunted by her feverish apprehensions,

8915.text:
she could not bear to have her sight obscured
for a minute at a time by the dripping water,

8921.text:
but constantly paused and looked round to
see that there was no one watching her. In

8926.text:
one of those pauses she recoiled and cried
out, for she saw a figure standing in the

8932.text:
room.
The basin fell to the ground broken, and the

8936.text:
water flowed to the feet of Madame Defarge.
By strange stern ways, and through much staining

8943.text:
blood, those feet had come to meet that water.
Madame Defarge looked coldly at her, and said,

8951.text:
"The wife of Evremonde; where is she?"
It flashed upon Miss Pross's mind that the

8958.text:
doors were all standing open, and would suggest
the flight. Her first act was to shut them.

8964.text:
There were four in the room, and she shut
them all. She then placed herself before the

8970.text:
door of the chamber which Lucie had occupied.
Madame Defarge's dark eyes followed her through

8976.text:
this rapid movement, and rested on her when
it was finished. Miss Pross had nothing beautiful

8982.text:
about her; years had not tamed the wildness,
or softened the grimness, of her appearance;

8988.text:
but, she too was a determined woman in her
different way, and she measured Madame Defarge

8994.text:
with her eyes, every inch.
"You might, from your appearance, be the wife

9000.text:
of Lucifer," said Miss Pross, in her breathing.
"Nevertheless, you shall not get the better

9006.text:
of me. I am an Englishwoman."
Madame Defarge looked at her scornfully, but

9014.text:
still with something of Miss Pross's own perception
that they two were at bay. She saw a tight,

9022.text:
hard, wiry woman before her, as Mr. Lorry
had seen in the same figure a woman with a

9028.text:
strong hand, in the years gone by. She knew
full well that Miss Pross was the family's

9034.text:
devoted friend; Miss Pross knew full well
that Madame Defarge was the family's malevolent

9041.text:
enemy.
"On my way yonder," said Madame Defarge, with

9046.text:
a slight movement of her hand towards the
fatal spot, "where they reserve my chair and

9052.text:
my knitting for me, I am come to make my compliments
to her in passing. I wish to see her."

9059.text:
"I know that your intentions are evil," said
Miss Pross, "and you may depend upon it, I'll

9065.text:
hold my own against them."
Each spoke in her own language; neither understood

9071.text:
the other's words; both were very watchful,
and intent to deduce from look and manner,

9078.text:
what the unintelligible words meant.
"It will do her no good to keep herself concealed

9084.text:
from me at this moment," said Madame Defarge.
"Good patriots will know what that means.

9091.text:
Let me see her. Go tell her that I wish to
see her. Do you hear?"

9095.text:
"If those eyes of yours were bed-winches,"
returned Miss Pross, "and I was an English

9100.text:
four-poster, they shouldn't loose a splinter
of me. No, you wicked foreign woman; I am

9107.text:
your match."
Madame Defarge was not likely to follow these

9112.text:
idiomatic remarks in detail; but, she so far
understood them as to perceive that she was

9119.text:
set at naught.
"Woman imbecile and pig-like!" said Madame

9124.text:
Defarge, frowning. "I take no answer from
you. I demand to see her. Either tell her

9130.text:
that I demand to see her, or stand out of
the way of the door and let me go to her!"

9135.text:
This, with an angry explanatory wave of her
right arm.

9140.text:
"I little thought," said Miss Pross, "that
I should ever want to understand your nonsensical

9146.text:
language; but I would give all I have, except
the clothes I wear, to know whether you suspect

9152.text:
the truth, or any part of it."
Neither of them for a single moment released

9157.text:
the other's eyes. Madame Defarge had not moved
from the spot where she stood when Miss Pross

9164.text:
first became aware of her; but, she now advanced
one step.

9169.text:
"I am a Briton," said Miss Pross, "I am desperate.
I don't care an English Twopence for myself.

9177.text:
I know that the longer I keep you here, the
greater hope there is for my Ladybird. I'll

9182.text:
not leave a handful of that dark hair upon
your head, if you lay a finger on me!"

9189.text:
Thus Miss Pross, with a shake of her head
and a flash of her eyes between every rapid

9194.text:
sentence, and every rapid sentence a whole
breath. Thus Miss Pross, who had never struck

9200.text:
a blow in her life.
But, her courage was of that emotional nature

9206.text:
that it brought the irrepressible tears into
her eyes. This was a courage that Madame Defarge

9212.text:
so little comprehended as to mistake for weakness.
"Ha, ha!" she laughed, "you poor wretch! What

9219.text:
are you worth! I address myself to that Doctor."
Then she raised her voice and called out,

9226.text:
"Citizen Doctor! Wife of Evremonde! Child
of Evremonde! Any person but this miserable

9232.text:
fool, answer the Citizeness Defarge!"
Perhaps the following silence, perhaps some

9239.text:
latent disclosure in the expression of Miss
Pross's face, perhaps a sudden misgiving apart

9245.text:
from either suggestion, whispered to Madame
Defarge that they were gone. Three of the

9251.text:
doors she opened swiftly, and looked in.
"Those rooms are all in disorder, there has

9257.text:
been hurried packing, there are odds and ends
upon the ground. There is no one in that room

9261.text:
behind you! Let me look."
"Never!" said Miss Pross, who understood the

9266.text:
request as perfectly as Madame Defarge understood
the answer.

9270.text:
"If they are not in that room, they are gone,
and can be pursued and brought back," said

9276.text:
Madame Defarge to herself.
"As long as you don't know whether they are

9280.text:
in that room or not, you are uncertain what
to do," said Miss Pross to herself; "and you

9286.text:
shall not know that, if I can prevent your
knowing it; and know that, or not know that,

9291.text:
you shall not leave here while I can hold
you."

9294.text:
"I have been in the streets from the first,
nothing has stopped me, I will tear you to

9300.text:
pieces, but I will have you from that door,"
said Madame Defarge.

9305.text:
"We are alone at the top of a high house in
a solitary courtyard, we are not likely to

9311.text:
be heard, and I pray for bodily strength to
keep you here, while every minute you are

9317.text:
here is worth a hundred thousand guineas to
my darling," said Miss Pross.

9324.text:
Madame Defarge made at the door. Miss Pross,
on the instinct of the moment, seized her

9329.text:
round the waist in both her arms, and held
her tight. It was in vain for Madame Defarge

9334.text:
to struggle and to strike; Miss Pross, with
the vigorous tenacity of love, always so much

9341.text:
stronger than hate, clasped her tight, and
even lifted her from the floor in the struggle

9346.text:
that they had. The two hands of Madame Defarge
buffeted and tore her face; but, Miss Pross,

9353.text:
with her head down, held her round the waist,
and clung to her with more than the hold of

9359.text:
a drowning woman.
Soon, Madame Defarge's hands ceased to strike,

9365.text:
and felt at her encircled waist. "It is under
my arm," said Miss Pross, in smothered tones,

9372.text:
"you shall not draw it. I am stronger than
you, I bless Heaven for it. I hold you till

9378.text:
one or other of us faints or dies!"
Madame Defarge's hands were at her bosom.

9385.text:
Miss Pross looked up, saw what it was, struck
at it, struck out a flash and a crash, and

9392.text:
stood alone—blinded with smoke.
All this was in a second. As the smoke cleared,

9398.text:
leaving an awful stillness, it passed out
on the air, like the soul of the furious woman

9405.text:
whose body lay lifeless on the ground.
In the first fright and horror of her situation,

9414.text:
Miss Pross passed the body as far from it
as she could, and ran down the stairs to call

9420.text:
for fruitless help. Happily, she bethought
herself of the consequences of what she did,

9426.text:
in time to check herself and go back. It was
dreadful to go in at the door again; but,

9431.text:
she did go in, and even went near it, to get
the bonnet and other things that she must

9437.text:
wear. These she put on, out on the staircase,
first shutting and locking the door and taking

9444.text:
away the key. She then sat down on the stairs
a few moments to breathe and to cry, and then

9450.text:
got up and hurried away.
By good fortune she had a veil on her bonnet,

9456.text:
or she could hardly have gone along the streets
without being stopped. By good fortune, too,

9462.text:
she was naturally so peculiar in appearance
as not to show disfigurement like any other

9468.text:
woman. She needed both advantages, for the
marks of gripping fingers were deep in her

9473.text:
face, and her hair was torn, and her dress
(hastily composed with unsteady hands) was

9480.text:
clutched and dragged a hundred ways.
In crossing the bridge, she dropped the door

9487.text:
key in the river. Arriving at the cathedral
some few minutes before her escort, and waiting

9493.text:
there, she thought, what if the key were already
taken in a net, what if it were identified,

9499.text:
what if the door were opened and the remains
discovered, what if she were stopped at the

9503.text:
gate, sent to prison, and charged with murder!
In the midst of these fluttering thoughts,

9510.text:
the escort appeared, took her in, and took
her away.

9513.text:
"Is there any noise in the streets?" she asked
him.

9517.text:
"The usual noises," Mr. Cruncher replied;
and looked surprised by the question and by

9522.text:
her aspect.
"I don't hear you," said Miss Pross. "What

9526.text:
do you say?"
It was in vain for Mr. Cruncher to repeat

9529.text:
what he said; Miss Pross could not hear him.
"So I'll nod my head," thought Mr. Cruncher,

9536.text:
amazed, "at all events she'll see that." And
she did.

9540.text:
"Is there any noise in the streets now?" asked
Miss Pross again, presently.

9544.text:
Again Mr. Cruncher nodded his head.
"I don't hear it."

9550.text:
"Gone deaf in an hour?" said Mr. Cruncher,
ruminating, with his mind much disturbed;

9556.text:
"wot's come to her?"
"I feel," said Miss Pross, "as if there had

9561.text:
been a flash and a crash, and that crash was
the last thing I should ever hear in this

9567.text:
life."
"Blest if she ain't in a queer condition!"

9571.text:
said Mr. Cruncher, more and more disturbed.
"Wot can she have been a takin', to keep her

9576.text:
courage up? Hark! There's the roll of them
dreadful carts! You can hear that, miss?"

9582.text:
"I can hear," said Miss Pross, seeing that
he spoke to her, "nothing. O, my good man,

9588.text:
there was first a great crash, and then a
great stillness, and that stillness seems

9594.text:
to be fixed and unchangeable, never to be
broken any more as long as my life lasts."

9601.text:
"If she don't hear the roll of those dreadful
carts, now very nigh their journey's end,"

9607.text:
said Mr. Cruncher, glancing over his shoulder,
"it's my opinion that indeed she never will

9613.text:
hear anything else in this world."
And indeed she never did.

9626.text:
Chapter XV. The Footsteps Die Out For Ever
Along the Paris streets, the death-carts rumble,

9635.text:
hollow and harsh. Six tumbrils carry the day's
wine to La Guillotine. All the devouring and

9643.text:
insatiate Monsters imagined since imagination
could record itself, are fused in the one

9649.text:
realisation, Guillotine. And yet there is
not in France, with its rich variety of soil

9657.text:
and climate, a blade, a leaf, a root, a sprig,
a peppercorn, which will grow to maturity

9664.text:
under conditions more certain than those that
have produced this horror. Crush humanity

9670.text:
out of shape once more, under similar hammers,
and it will twist itself into the same tortured

9677.text:
forms. Sow the same seed of rapacious license
and oppression over again, and it will surely

9684.text:
yield the same fruit according to its kind.
Six tumbrils roll along the streets. Change

9692.text:
these back again to what they were, thou powerful
enchanter, Time, and they shall be seen to

9698.text:
be the carriages of absolute monarchs, the
equipages of feudal nobles, the toilettes

9705.text:
of flaring Jezebels, the churches that are
not my father's house but dens of thieves,

9712.text:
the huts of millions of starving peasants!
No; the great magician who majestically works

9719.text:
out the appointed order of the Creator, never
reverses his transformations. "If thou be

9728.text:
changed into this shape by the will of God,"
say the seers to the enchanted, in the wise

9734.text:
Arabian stories, "then remain so! But, if
thou wear this form through mere passing conjuration,

9741.text:
then resume thy former aspect!" Changeless
and hopeless, the tumbrils roll along.

9751.text:
As the sombre wheels of the six carts go round,
they seem to plough up a long crooked furrow

9758.text:
among the populace in the streets. Ridges
of faces are thrown to this side and to that,

9764.text:
and the ploughs go steadily onward. So used
are the regular inhabitants of the houses

9770.text:
to the spectacle, that in many windows there
are no people, and in some the occupation

9776.text:
of the hands is not so much as suspended,
while the eyes survey the faces in the tumbrils.

9783.text:
Here and there, the inmate has visitors to
see the sight; then he points his finger,

9789.text:
with something of the complacency of a curator
or authorised exponent, to this cart and to

9796.text:
this, and seems to tell who sat here yesterday,
and who there the day before.

9802.text:
Of the riders in the tumbrils, some observe
these things, and all things on their last

9808.text:
roadside, with an impassive stare; others,
with a lingering interest in the ways of life

9815.text:
and men. Some, seated with drooping heads,
are sunk in silent despair; again, there are

9823.text:
some so heedful of their looks that they cast
upon the multitude such glances as they have

9829.text:
seen in theatres, and in pictures. Several
close their eyes, and think, or try to get

9835.text:
their straying thoughts together. Only one,
and he a miserable creature, of a crazed aspect,

9843.text:
is so shattered and made drunk by horror,
that he sings, and tries to dance. Not one

9850.text:
of the whole number appeals by look or gesture,
to the pity of the people.

9857.text:
There is a guard of sundry horsemen riding
abreast of the tumbrils, and faces are often

9862.text:
turned up to some of them, and they are asked
some question. It would seem to be always

9868.text:
the same question, for, it is always followed
by a press of people towards the third cart.

9875.text:
The horsemen abreast of that cart, frequently
point out one man in it with their swords.

9881.text:
The leading curiosity is, to know which is
he; he stands at the back of the tumbril with

9887.text:
his head bent down, to converse with a mere
girl who sits on the side of the cart, and

9894.text:
holds his hand. He has no curiosity or care
for the scene about him, and always speaks

9900.text:
to the girl. Here and there in the long street
of St. Honore, cries are raised against him.

9907.text:
If they move him at all, it is only to a quiet
smile, as he shakes his hair a little more

9913.text:
loosely about his face. He cannot easily touch
his face, his arms being bound.

9920.text:
On the steps of a church, awaiting the coming-up
of the tumbrils, stands the Spy and prison-sheep.

9927.text:
He looks into the first of them: not there.
He looks into the second: not there. He already

9933.text:
asks himself, "Has he sacrificed me?" when
his face clears, as he looks into the third.

9939.text:
"Which is Evremonde?" says a man behind him.
"That. At the back there."

9950.text:
The man cries, "Down, Evremonde! To the Guillotine
all aristocrats! Down, Evremonde!"

9957.text:
"Hush, hush!" the Spy entreats him, timidly.
"And why not, citizen?"

9963.text:
"He is going to pay the forfeit: it will be
paid in five minutes more. Let him be at peace."

9971.text:
But the man continuing to exclaim, "Down,
Evremonde!" the face of Evremonde is for a

9978.text:
moment turned towards him. Evremonde then
sees the Spy, and looks attentively at him,

9984.text:
and goes his way.
The clocks are on the stroke of three, and

9989.text:
the furrow ploughed among the populace is
turning round, to come on into the place of

9995.text:
execution, and end. The ridges thrown to this
side and to that, now crumble in and close

10002.text:
behind the last plough as it passes on, for
all are following to the Guillotine. In front

10009.text:
of it, seated in chairs, as in a garden of
public diversion, are a number of women, busily

10017.text:
knitting. On one of the fore-most chairs,
stands The Vengeance, looking about for her

10022.text:
friend.
"Therese!" she cries, in her shrill tones.

10026.text:
"Who has seen her? Therese Defarge!"
"She never missed before," says a knitting-woman

10032.text:
of the sisterhood.
"No; nor will she miss now," cries The Vengeance,

10043.text:
Ay! Louder, Vengeance, much louder, and still
she will scarcely hear thee. Louder yet, Vengeance,

10051.text:
with a little oath or so added, and yet it
will hardly bring her. Send other women up

10057.text:
and down to seek her, lingering somewhere;
and yet, although the messengers have done

10062.text:
dread deeds, it is questionable whether of
their own wills they will go far enough to

10068.text:
find her!
"Bad Fortune!" cries The Vengeance, stamping

10074.text:
her foot in the chair, "and here are the tumbrils!
And Evremonde will be despatched in a wink,

10079.text:
and she not here! See her knitting in my hand,
and her empty chair ready for her. I cry with

10086.text:
vexation and disappointment!"
As The Vengeance descends from her elevation

10093.text:
to do it, the tumbrils begin to discharge
their loads. The ministers of Sainte Guillotine

10099.text:
are robed and ready. Crash!—A head is held
up, and the knitting-women who scarcely lifted

10106.text:
their eyes to look at it a moment ago when
it could think and speak, count One.

10113.text:
The second tumbril empties and moves on; the
third comes up. Crash!—And the knitting-women,

10119.text:
never faltering or pausing in their Work,
count Two.

10124.text:
The supposed Evremonde descends, and the seamstress
is lifted out next after him. He has not relinquished

10132.text:
her patient hand in getting out, but still
holds it as he promised. He gently places

10138.text:
her with her back to the crashing engine that
constantly whirrs up and falls, and she looks

10144.text:
into his face and thanks him.
"But for you, dear stranger, I should not

10150.text:
be so composed, for I am naturally a poor
little thing, faint of heart; nor should I

10157.text:
have been able to raise my thoughts to Him
who was put to death, that we might have hope

10162.text:
and comfort here to-day. I think you were
sent to me by Heaven."

10167.text:
"Or you to me," says Sydney Carton. "Keep
your eyes upon me, dear child, and mind no

10174.text:
other object."
"I mind nothing while I hold your hand. I

10179.text:
shall mind nothing when I let it go, if they
are rapid."

10182.text:
"They will be rapid. Fear not!"
The two stand in the fast-thinning throng

10188.text:
of victims, but they speak as if they were
alone. Eye to eye, voice to voice, hand to

10195.text:
hand, heart to heart, these two children of
the Universal Mother, else so wide apart and

10203.text:
differing, have come together on the dark
highway, to repair home together, and to rest

10209.text:
in her bosom.
"Brave and generous friend, will you let me

10213.text:
ask you one last question? I am very ignorant,
and it troubles me—just a little."

10219.text:
"Tell me what it is."
"I have a cousin, an only relative and an

10225.text:
orphan, like myself, whom I love very dearly.
She is five years younger than I, and she

10231.text:
lives in a farmer's house in the south country.
Poverty parted us, and she knows nothing of

10237.text:
my fate—for I cannot write—and if I could,
how should I tell her! It is better as it

10243.text:
is."
"Yes, yes: better as it is."

10247.text:
"What I have been thinking as we came along,
and what I am still thinking now, as I look

10253.text:
into your kind strong face which gives me
so much support, is this:—If the Republic

10260.text:
really does good to the poor, and they come
to be less hungry, and in all ways to suffer

10266.text:
less, she may live a long time: she may even
live to be old."

10270.text:
"What then, my gentle sister?"
"Do you think:" the uncomplaining eyes in

10277.text:
which there is so much endurance, fill with
tears, and the lips part a little more and

10284.text:
tremble: "that it will seem long to me, while
I wait for her in the better land where I

10289.text:
trust both you and I will be mercifully sheltered?"
"It cannot be, my child; there is no Time

10296.text:
there, and no trouble there."
"You comfort me so much! I am so ignorant.

10302.text:
Am I to kiss you now? Is the moment come?"
"Yes."

10310.text:
She kisses his lips; he kisses hers; they
solemnly bless each other. The spare hand

10317.text:
does not tremble as he releases it; nothing
worse than a sweet, bright constancy is in

10323.text:
the patient face. She goes next before him—is
gone; the knitting-women count Twenty-Two.

10331.text:
"I am the Resurrection and the Life, saith
the Lord: he that believeth in me, though

10340.text:
he were dead, yet shall he live: and whosoever
liveth and believeth in me shall never die."

10348.text:
The murmuring of many voices, the upturning
of many faces, the pressing on of many footsteps

10354.text:
in the outskirts of the crowd, so that it
swells forward in a mass, like one great heave

10361.text: of water, all flashes away. Twenty-Three.

10367.text:
*****
They said of him, about the city that night,

10370.text:
that it was the peacefullest man's face ever
beheld there. Many added that he looked sublime

10376.text:
and prophetic.
One of the most remarkable sufferers by the

10381.text:
same axe—a woman—had asked at the foot
of the same scaffold, not long before, to

10386.text:
be allowed to write down the thoughts that
were inspiring her. If he had given any utterance

10392.text:
to his, and they were prophetic, they would
have been these:

10396.text:
"I see Barsad, and Cly, Defarge, The Vengeance,
the Juryman, the Judge, long ranks of the

10404.text:
new oppressors who have risen on the destruction
of the old, perishing by this retributive

10410.text:
instrument, before it shall cease out of its
present use. I see a beautiful city and a

10417.text:
brilliant people rising from this abyss, and,
in their struggles to be truly free, in their

10423.text:
triumphs and defeats, through long years to
come, I see the evil of this time and of the

10430.text:
previous time of which this is the natural
birth, gradually making expiation for itself

10437.text:
and wearing out.
"I see the lives for which I lay down my life,

10443.text:
peaceful, useful, prosperous and happy, in
that England which I shall see no more. I

10451.text:
see Her with a child upon her bosom, who bears
my name. I see her father, aged and bent,

10459.text:
but otherwise restored, and faithful to all
men in his healing office, and at peace. I

10466.text:
see the good old man, so long their friend,
in ten years' time enriching them with all

10472.text:
he has, and passing tranquilly to his reward.
"I see that I hold a sanctuary in their hearts,

10480.text:
and in the hearts of their descendants, generations
hence. I see her, an old woman, weeping for

10488.text:
me on the anniversary of this day. I see her
and her husband, their course done, lying

10495.text:
side by side in their last earthly bed, and
I know that each was not more honoured and

10502.text:
held sacred in the other's soul, than I was
in the souls of both.

10507.text:
"I see that child who lay upon her bosom and
who bore my name, a man winning his way up

10514.text:
in that path of life which once was mine.
I see him winning it so well, that my name

10520.text:
is made illustrious there by the light of
his. I see the blots I threw upon it, faded

10528.text:
away. I see him, fore-most of just judges
and honoured men, bringing a boy of my name,

10536.text:
with a forehead that I know and golden hair,
to this place—then fair to look upon, with

10542.text:
not a trace of this day's disfigurement—and
I hear him tell the child my story, with a

10549.text:
tender and a faltering voice.
"It is a far, far better thing that I do,

10557.text:
than I have ever done; it is a far, far better
rest that I go to than I have ever known."

End of Book 3, Chapter 15
End of A Tale of Two Cities
